verses.verse: ((1 Moses in his prayer setteth before us the eternal favor of God toward his,3 who are neither admonished by the brevity of their life, 7 nor by his plagues to be thankful,12 therefore Moses prayeth God to turn their hearts, and continue his mercies toward them and their posterity forever.) Lord, thou hast been our (Thou hast been as an house and defense unto us in all our troubles and travels now this four hundred years.) habitation from generation to generation.

Before the (Thou hast chosen us to be thy people before the foundations of the world were laid.) mountains were made, and before thou hadst formed the earth, and the world, even from everlasting to everlasting thou art our God.
Thou (Moses by lamenting the frailty and shortness of man’s life moveth God to pity.) turnest man to destruction: again thou sayest, Return ye sons of Adam.

(Though man thinks his life long, which is indeed most short, yea though it were a thousand years: yet in God’s sight it is as nothing, and as the watch that lasteth but three hours.) For a thousand years in thy sight are as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night.
Thou hast (Thou takest them away suddenly as with a flood.) overflowed them, they are as a sleep, in the morning he groweth like the grass:
In the morning it flourisheth and groweth, but in the evening it is cut down and withereth.
For we are (Thou callest us by thy rods to consider the shortness of our life, and for our sins thou abridgest our days.) consumed by thine anger, and by thy wrath are we troubled.
Thou hast set our iniquities before thee, and our secret sins in the light of thy countenance.
For all our days are past in thine anger: we have (Our days are not only short, but miserable, forasmuch as our sins daily provoke thy wrath.) spent our years as a thought.

The time of our life is threescore years and ten, and if they be of strength, (Meaning, according to the common state of life.) fourscore years: yet their strength is but labor and sorrow: for it is cut off quickly, and we flee away.
(If man’s life for the brevity be miserable, much more if thy wrath lie upon it, as they which fear thee, only know.) Who knoweth the power of thy wrath? for according to thy fear is thine anger.
Teach us so to number our days, that we may apply our hearts unto (Which is, by considering the shortness of our life, and by meditating the heavenly joys.) wisdom.
Return (O Lord, (Meaning, wilt thou be angry?) how long?) and be (Or, take comfort in thy servants.) pacified toward thy servants.
Fill us with thy mercy in the morning: so shall we rejoice and be glad all our days?
Comfort us according to the days that thou hast afflicted us, and according to the years that we have seen evil.

(Even thy mercy, which is the chiefest work.) Let thy work be seen toward thy servants, and thy glory upon their (As God’s promises appertained as well to their posterity, as to them, so Moses prayeth for the posterity.) children.

And let the (Meaning, that is was obscured, when he ceaseth to do good to his Church.) beauty of the Lord our God be upon us, and (For except thou guide us with thine holy Spirit, our enterprises can have no good success.) direct thou the work of our hands upon us, even direct the work of our hands.
